title: Over 1,500 learners caught CHEATING in driving theory tests last year
text:
The number of learners attempting to cheat their way through their driving theory test are on the rise, according to a new report.

Data from the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agency shows that 1,522 people were investigated for cheating in their theory test in the financial year 2018/19.

That's more than triple the number caught five years ago (454 cases), according to the DVSA's fraud department.

Cheats: Over 1,500 learners were investigated in the previous financial year for attempting to con their way through the driving theory test, reports Auto Express

Cases of learners attempting to con their driving theory examinations are likely to increase again this year, warns Auto Express.

The car magazine said figures it received from the DVSA showed that over 1,000 learners have been suspected for cheating already in the first five months of this financial year.

According to its estimates, at that rate almost 2,500 people could be reprimanded for trying to trick their way through the test.

It said the huge increase in the last half a decade is down to the DVSA's decision to take prosecutions for theory test fraud in-house.

Number of learners caught cheating the driving theory test 2013/14: 454 2014/15: 735 2015/16: 672 2016/17: 810 2017/18: 579 2018/19: 1522 1 April- 3 September 2019: 1009 Source: AutoExpress using DVSA stats

Previously it had to rely on independent investigators and the Crown Prosecution Service to bring cases to court, but now has the powers to sanction those it has found cheating.

Those found guilty of cheating the exam face a custodial sentence imposed by courts, and DVSA's policy is to prosecute all cases if 'evidence show[s] that a criminal offence has occurred', it told Auto Express.

Today's driving theory test consists of 50 multiple choice questions and a hazard perception videos.

The required pass mark is 43 out of the 50 questions and for learners to successfully identify a minimum of 44 hazards out of the 75 dangers that appear in the video clips.

To ensure that those sitting the test aren't trying to cheat the system, the DVSA uses CCTV cameras to monitor all examination rooms.

Trained investigators oversee the live footage, looking for telltale signs of fraudulent activity.

Some learners were caught using small Bluetooth earphones during exams to speak to someone outside the examination room who could relay correct answers over the phone

The agency said there are two common ways people are trying to swindle their way through the current test.

The first is to use hidden Bluetooth headsets to read questions to an accomplice at the other end of the phone who can relay correct answers back from outside the examination room.

The second method is to have another person - usually well-versed in the test questions - sit the exam under their name, either as a favour for for financial gain.

While the volume of fraudulent theory test cases are on the rise, they represent a tiny proportion of the 1.8million driving exams sat every year.

Almost 1.8 million learners took the driving theory test last year, but less than half (47.3%) passed the exam

During the 2018/2019 financial year, records show that 1,787,773 people took the theory test - suggesting that fraudulent cases make up around just 0.09 per cent.

In that time, 845,028 learners passed the theory test - a success rate of 47.3 per cent.

Andy Rice, the DVSA’s head of counter-fraud and investigation told Auto Express that his organisation takes 'the strongest possible action against anyone caught cheating the theory test'.

Sarah Rees, managing director of the AA Driving School, added that by cheating in the test, guilty parties will be putting themselves and other road users at risk because they 'may not have the necessary knowledge to navigate our roads properly'.

'Hopefully anyone considering cheating will be put off by these figures and earn their driving licence the proper way,' she added.
